name: Jaycen
comment info: The graphs show trends in health-related behaviors among US high school students from 1989 to 2019. The data is based on surveys of more than 10,000 high school students from public and private schools across the country, collected by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) as part of the Youth Risk Behavior Surveillance System (YRBSS), which monitors six categories of health-related behaviors. The ten graphs show trends in behaviors such as tobacco and drug use, sexual activity, physical activity, and mental health. The data shows that while some behaviors have improved over the years, such as the decline in cigarette and alcohol use, others have become more prevalent, such as the increase in mental health problems like anxiety, depression, and suicide ideation. The story that the graphs tell is that there has been a significant shift in the health-related behaviors of US high school students over the past 30 years, with some positive changes, but also some concerning negative trends.

name: Jaycen
comment info: The article presents two graphs that illustrate the trends in health-related behaviors among high school students from 1989 to 2019, before the Covid pandemic. The data was gathered from more than 10,000 U.S. high school students from public and private schools across the country by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). The statistics describe behaviors of teenagers in six categories of health-related behaviors, including unintentional injuries and violence, sexual behaviors, alcohol, tobacco and other drug use, unhealthy dietary behaviors and inadequate physical activity. The graphs show a decrease in cigarette smoking and sexual activity, an increase in the use of electronic cigarettes and marijuana, and no significant change in other behaviors, such as alcohol consumption and physical activity. The article also discusses the mental health crisis among U.S. teens, examining the increase in anxiety, depression, self-harm, and suicide. The article provides resources for parents and teenagers dealing with these issues.

name: Jaycen
comment info: These graphs show the trends in health-related behaviors among high school students from 1989 to 2019. The data was collected by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) through surveys of more than 10,000 U.S. high school students from public and private schools across the country, and it describes behaviors of teenagers before the Covid pandemic. The graphs reveal changes in the prevalence and severity of behaviors related to physical activity, nutrition, substance use, and sexual activity over time. For instance, the data shows that from 1989 to 2019, high school students have been consuming fewer fruits and vegetables, drinking less milk, engaging in less physical activity, and having less sex, but they have also been using electronic cigarettes, marijuana, and prescription drugs more frequently. The graphs provide important insights into the health behaviors of American teenagers and can help identify areas where more intervention and prevention efforts may be needed.

Headline: Cause and Effect in a Daily Teen's Life

replies.name: M
replies.comment info:
Hi @Liam, 
Regarding your last comment about seeing people who smoke and noting those same people look unhappy, I see you are wondering if it's fair to conclude their smoking habit was caused by their depressed feelings.  Indeed it's very human to notice an association and want to believe it's causal, but it's crucial not to draw that conclusion! There are many other plausible reasons for the association, such as that some other underlying issue in the person's life (anxiety, stress) is causing both. Or that smoking has directly or indirectly caused the depression. It's also possible that it's a coincidental association. And of course the other big thinking error is to move from anecdotal observations (such as you observing people in your neighborhood) to generalizing to a larger population without data. In fact, what about the set of graphs might contradict your conclusions regarding the link between smoking/drinking habits and happiness?

comment info:
The upper set of graphs shows declines in risky behavior: vaping, smoking , using alcohol and cocaine, and having unprotected sex.  Use of marijuana is on the rise again (30%).

Trends in the upper set of graphs seems more positive; the lower set of graphs presents a different picture: between 2009 and 2019, teens feeling sadness and hopelessness are on the rise, as are the number of those who seriously considered suicide, those who made a suicide plan, and those who attempted suicide.
I wonder if there is a correlation between lack of traditional methods of “escape” (alcohol, tobacco) and the rise in feelings of negativity. Or does the rise in marijuana use cause paranoid reactions that lead to the rise in feelings that lead some to consider and even attempt suicide?
This impacts my community because it is largely populated with teens whose behavior, beliefs, and states of mind may be reflected in the data shown in these graphs. It means that many of my students are not getting enough sleep, are persistently feeling hopeless or sad, and most troubling is the rise in considerations of suicide.
A potential headline:  “Is a Gram Better Than a Damn?”.

name: Sharon Hessney
comment info:
Welcome to Wednesday's live moderation of “What’s Going On in This Graph?”  We will moderate until 2 pm ET.

Today’s graphs show the change in teen behaviors over a 30 year period (1989 – 2019) based on survey data by the CDC from thousands of high school students in private and public schools across the country.  Note that the time period precedes the Covid pandemic.

From 9 am – 2 pm E.T. today, share with us your responses online to these three questions -- "What do you notice?",  "What do you wonder?"  and “How will this affect you?”  Plus, please share with us a catchy headline that captures the ideas in these graphs. 

By Friday morning, we’ll reveal the free link to the online article that included these graphs 
 
Note that you can get a link to your response (and replies made to it) to share with your teacher and classmates by clicking the response box below your response “Email me when my comment is published.”  

Please visit our archive to see all graphs in this series (tinyurl.com/NYTGraphs).
View our archives that link to all past releases, organized by topic (tinyurl.com/NYTGraphsTopicIndex), 
graph type (tinyurl.com/NYTGraphsTypeIndex) and 
Stat Nugget (tinyurl.com/NYTGraphsStatNuggetsIndex).  

This is the last release of the school year. We will return in early September. You can receive the 2022-2023 “What’s Going On In This Graph?” schedule by subscribing to the New York Times Learning Network newsletter. In the meantime, keep noticing and wondering.

name: William
comment info:
1. Suicide-related issues are more prominent within the past ~10 years than previously before.
2. What's changed since 2009 to cause this influx of suicidal thoughts among teenagers? Could it have something to do with the use of vapes among teenagers?
3. Suicide is more openly-talked about both among adults and teenagers, and awareness has increased. At the same time, however, suicide rates are increasing.
4. Suicide and depression rates increase when technology use rates increase.

replies.comment info:
HI, @William --

What evidence do you have that “Suicide and depression rates increase when technology use rates increase.”?  

Can you reach this conclusion from a survey?  The answer is no.  You can only confirm a cause-and-effect if you have a controlled experiment, where you test for a factor.  

Could you do an experiment in this case?  I would say yes if the explanatory variable is, say, reduced smartphone use and the response is a measurement of sadness or hopeless.  How could you design an experiment?

name: Ken
comment info:
Persistently felt sad or hopeless. Worrying trend and high percentages already. A few things strike me here:
1. How was the questions phrased to the participants? What does "persistent" actually mean ? How do we define sad and hopeless? How can we quantify qualitative, emotion-based data?
2.  What might be some of the drivers for triggering sadness and hopelessness?
3. Why such a huge disparity between Male and Female?

replies.comment info:
HI, @Ken --

You are focusing on the wording of the questions.  Search for CDC teen survey questionnaire.   There you will find many of the CDC questionnaires.  

The questions have been tested and are most are used for many years so the statistics can be compared.  Using words like “persistent”, “sad” and “hopeless” have apparently produced consistent and revealing results.
